sourcesContent:
import React, { useState } from 'react'; import { useNavigate } from 'react-router-dom'; import { useProgress } from '../contexts/ProgressContext'; const modules = [ { id: 1, title: 'Introduction to Indian Constitution', description: 'Learn about the history and basic structure of the Indian Constitution.', content: ` The Constitution of India is the supreme law of India. It lays down the framework defining fundamental political principles, establishes the structure, procedures, powers, and duties of government institutions, and sets out fundamental rights, directive principles, and the duties of citizens. Key Points: - Adopted on 26 November 1949 - Came into effect on 26 January 1950 - Longest written constitution of any sovereign country - Contains 395 articles in 22 parts and 8 schedules - Declares India a sovereign, socialist, secular, democratic republic The Constitution was drafted by the Constituent Assembly, which was established in 1946. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar served as the Chairman of the Drafting Committee. The Constitution draws inspiration from various sources, including: - Government of India Act 1935 - British Constitution - US Constitution - Irish Constitution - French Constitution The Constitution provides a comprehensive framework for: 1. Governance structure 2. Fundamental rights 3. Directive principles 4. Fundamental duties 5. Distribution of powers 6. Emergency provisions `, timeEstimate: 15, points: 50 }, { id: 2, title: 'Fundamental Rights', description: 'Explore the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Indian Constitution.', content: ` Fundamental Rights are the basic human rights enshrined in the Constitution of India which are guaranteed to all citizens. They are enforceable by courts, subject to specific restrictions. The six fundamental rights are: 1. Right to Equality (Articles 14-18) - Equality before law - Prohibition of discrimination - Equality of opportunity - Abolition of untouchability - Abolition of titles 2. Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22) - Freedom of speech and expression - Freedom of assembly - Freedom of association - Freedom of movement - Freedom of residence - Freedom of profession 3. Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24) - Prohibition of traffic in human beings - Prohibition of forced labor - Prohibition of child labor 4. Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28) - Freedom of conscience and religion - Freedom to manage religious affairs - Freedom from religious taxation - Freedom from religious instruction 5. Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30) - Protection of interests of minorities - Right of minorities to establish educational institutions 6. Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32) - Right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental Rights `, timeEstimate: 20, points: 75 }, { id: 3, title: 'Directive Principles of State Policy', description: 'Understand the guiding principles for governance of India.', content: ` Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP) are guidelines for the government to create conditions for ensuring social, economic, and political justice for all citizens. Key Features: - Not enforceable by courts - Fundamental in governance - Aim to establish welfare state - Inspired by Irish Constitution Major Categories: 1. Socialistic Principles - Adequate means of livelihood - Fair distribution of resources - Prevention of concentration of wealth - Equal pay for equal work - Protection of workers' rights 2. Gandhian Principles - Organization of village panchayats - Promotion of cottage industries - Prevention of cow slaughter - Prohibition of intoxicating drinks - Promotion of rural development 3. Liberal Intellectual Principles - Uniform civil code - Free legal aid - Separation of judiciary from executive - Protection of monuments - International peace and security Importance: 1. Help in interpretation of laws 2. Guide policy making 3. Promote welfare state 4. Balance individual rights with community needs `, timeEstimate: 18, points: 60 }, { id: 4, title: 'Federal Structure', description: 'Learn about the distribution of powers between Centre and States.', content: ` India has a federal structure with unitary features. The Constitution divides powers between the Centre (Union) and States. Features of Indian Federalism: 1. Dual Government 2. Written Constitution 3. Division of Powers 4. Independent Judiciary 5. Bicameral Legislature Distribution of Powers: 1. Union List (Article 246) - Defense - Foreign Affairs - Banking - Currency - Railways - Total 97 subjects 2. State List - Public Order - Police - Public Health - Agriculture - Total 66 subjects 3. Concurrent List - Education - Forest - Trade Unions - Marriage - Total 47 subjects Unitary Features: 1. Strong Centre 2. Single Constitution 3. Single Citizenship 4. Emergency Provisions 5. All-India Services `, timeEstimate: 25, points: 80 }, { id: 5, title: 'Constitutional Amendments', description: 'Explore how the Constitution can be amended and major amendments.', content: ` The Constitution can be amended through Article 368. This flexibility allows it to adapt to changing needs while maintaining its basic structure. Amendment Procedures: 1. Simple Majority - Changes in states' boundaries - Creation of new states - Changes in Schedules 2. Special Majority - 2/3 majority in both houses - Most constitutional provisions 3. Special Majority + State Ratification - Federal provisions - Election of President - Supreme Court - Distribution of powers Major Amendments: 1. First Amendment (1951) - Added Ninth Schedule - Modified right to freedom of speech - Provided for reservations 2. 42nd Amendment (1976) - Added words 'socialist', 'secular' - Added Fundamental Duties - Changed 'internal disturbance' to 'armed rebellion' 3. 73rd and 74th Amendments (1992) - Gave constitutional status to Panchayati Raj - Strengthened local governance 4. 86th Amendment (2002) - Made education a fundamental right - Added Article 21A `, timeEstimate: 22, points: 70 } ]; function Learn() { const [selectedModule, setSelectedModule] = useState(null); const { userProgress, completeModule } = useProgress(); const navigate = useNavigate(); const handleModuleComplete = (moduleId) => { completeModule(moduleId); setSelectedModule(null); }; const handleStartQuiz = () => { navigate('/quiz'); }; return (
{selectedModule ? (

{selectedModule.title}

{selectedModule.content.split('\n').map((paragraph, index) => (

{paragraph}

))}
) : ( <>

Learning Progress

Modules Completed {userProgress.modulesCompleted}/{modules.length}
{modules.map((module) => { const isCompleted = userProgress.completedModules.includes( module.id ); return (

{module.title}

{isCompleted && ( )}

{module.description}

{module.timeEstimate} minutes {module.points} points
); })}
)}
); } export default Learn;
